WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FAMILIES EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Hugh Sutherland
Address: R.R. #1, Butte, Sask.
Birthplace: Fife, Scotland

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1905
Where did you set up housekeeping? Log cabin, N.W. 36-35-24-W2
Where had you been living before that? England, B.C.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 1
How far was it to your nearest store? 16 miles, Humboldt
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once in two weeks
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, sugar, tea, molasses, pork, salt, dried fish, evaporated apples, tobacco, tomato paste, 3 flags, 25¢
Rolled oats

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Hammond Queen
Lake of the Woods Milling Co., 2nd Grade
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.40
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? That year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 75 cents
What other grain products did you use? None
Cornmeal? None
Whole wheat? None
Farina? None
Other? None
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? None
Hugh Sutherland
R.R. 1, Burr.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned mostly.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) **Well**.

How far was this water from your home? **50 yds**.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) **pail**.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Water was plentiful at first but after about 10 years became scarce and then we had to dig deep wells and lately dugouts.
There did you not water for drinking and for cooking? (gall., river, stream, depot) Well.

If so far was this water from your house? 50 yds.

Was this water brought to the house (gall., barrel, tank)? Yes.

Has any other supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you last visited this place? No.

Water was plentiful at first but after about 10 years became scarce and then we had to dig deep wells and lately dugouts.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought laundry soap.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Soap, wood ash, etc.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? Pikes growing locally.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Started using coal for heating about 1913 but still used wood for cooking.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? Forget.

What year was it purchased? 1905. Price? $20.00

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Tin.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Earthenware.

When did you first see enamel ware? 1905.

Aluminum? About 1876-1878.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

List any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Tea came in tin cans mostly 3 lb each.
Jam came in wooden pails mostly 5 lbs.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: oatmeal porridge with syrup, bread or bachelor biscuits with syrup & tea.

Dinner in winter: rabbit stewed or fried, potatoes, bread & tea. In summer: salt pork fried with potatoes, bread & tea.

Supper: bread and syrup with tea year 1905
1 member aged 27

18. What did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

1905........... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

West end Christmas dinner at my father's in Carleton

Menu: Roast Beef and a variety of vegetables, plum pudding, mince pies etc. And of course a nice dish of oxtail.

Present Mr. & Mrs. R.H. Cash, ages approx. 52. My wife & I ages approx. 29. Alice Allan 36. Hugh McDonald 34

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We were very tough in those days
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

not much difference in preparation of meals except the pressure cooker.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

not haven't done yet.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

Groceries were cheaper in the old days but we didn't have much money anyway, wheat sold for 60 cents per bushel for me, nonetheless, and we seldom got that. In 1907 we had a badly frozen crop and received about 25 cents at the local elevator. I used to buy my groceries from Tom Macdonald in Humboldt who now has a real estate office on 2nd Ave Saskatoon. He would be able to give the prices better than I can, as my memory isn't what it used to be.

Yours Truly,

H.S.
not much difference in preparation of meals except the pressure cooker.

21. When did you begin to rely on processed foods instead of home-made?

22. Please add other details you may have.

Groceries were cheaper in the old days but we didn't have much money anyway, although we got by on 6 cents per barrel of milk, and we seldom got that. In 1907 we had a fairly frugal year and received about $3 cents at the local theater.

I used to buy my groceries from Tom Macdonald, who now has a real estate office on Main Street. He arrived to able to serve the needs better than I can as my memory isn't total or word & be Yours Truly

S-X2
162. Sutherland, Hugh
